text: Uh, as a matter of fact, I I was trying
to think about my career since I left
the White House, and the best example I
have is a cartoon in a New Yorker a
couple years ago. This little boy is
looking up at his father. He says,
"Daddy, when I grow up, I want to be a
former president."
Well, I have had a great blessing as
former president because I've had an
access that no other very few other
people in the world have ever had to get
to know so many people around this whole
universe. Not only do I am I familiar
with the 50 states in the United States,
but also my wife and I have visited more
than 145 countries in the world and the
quarter center has had full-time
programs in 80 nations on earth. And a
lot of times when we go into a country,
we not only meet the king or the
president, but we also meet the
villagers who live in the most remote
areas of Africa. So our overall
commitment at the Carter Center is to
promote human rights. And knowing the
world as I do, I can tell you without
any equivocation that the number one
abuse of human rights on earth that's
strangely
not addressed quite often is the abuse
of women and girls.
There
there are a couple of reasons for this
that I'll mention to begin with. First
of all is a misinterpretation of
religious scriptures, holy scriptures in
the Bible, Old Testament, New Testament,
Quran and so forth. And these have been
misinterpreted by men who are now in the
ascendant positions in the synagogues
and the churches and in the mosques. And
they interpret these rules to make sure
that women are ordinarily relegated to a
secondary position with men compared to
men in the eyes of God. This is a very
serious problem. It's ordinarily not
addressed. A number of years ago in the
year 2000, I had been a Baptist, a
Southern Baptist for 200 years. I I
still teach Sunday school every Sunday.
I'll be teaching this Sunday as well.
But uh the Southern Baptist Convention
in that in the year 2000 decided that
women should play a secondary position
or subservient position to men. So they
issued edicts in effect that prevents
women from being priests, pastors,
deacons in the church or chaplain in the
military. And if a woman teaches a
classroom in a Southern Baptist
seminary, they cannot teach if a boy is
in the room because you can find verses
in the Bible that have over 30,000
verses in the Bible that say that a
woman shouldn't teach a man and so
forth. But the basic thing is that the
scriptures are misinterpreted to keep
men in an ascended position. That is an
all pervasive problem because the men
can
exert that power. And if a if an abusive
husband or an employer for instance
wants to cheat women, they can say,
"Well, if women are not equal in the
eyes of God, why should I treat them as
equals myself? How why should I pay them
equal pay for doing the same kind of
work?" The other very serious blight
that causes this problem is the
excessive resort to violence. And that
is increasing tremendously around the
world. Uh in the United States of
America for instance, we have had an
enormous increase in the abuse of poor
people, mostly mostly black people and
and minorities in by putting them in
prison. When I was in office as governor
of Georgia, one out of every 1,000
Americans were in prison. Nowadays, 7.3
people per thousand are in prison.
That's a sevenfold increase. And since I
left the White House, there's been an
800% increase in the number of women who
are black who are in prison. We also
have the only country on earth that
still has the death penalty. That is a
developed country. And we rank right
alongside the countries that are most
abusive in all elements of human rights
and encouraging the death penalty. We're
in California now. And I figured out the
other day that uh California has spent
$4 billion in convicting 13 people for
the best death penalty penalty. If you
add that up, that's $37 million it cost
California to send a person to be
executed. Nebraska this week just passed
a law abolishing the death penalty
because it cost so much.
So the resort to to violence and abuse
of poor people and helpless people is
another cause of the increase in abuse
of women. Let me just go down a very few
of the abuses of women that that concern
me most and and I'll be fairly brief
because I have a limited amount of time
as you know. One is the gen genital
mutilation.
Genital mutilation is horrible and not
known by American women. But uh in some
countries, many countries, when a a
child is born as a girl, very soon in
her life, her genitals are completely
cut away by a so-called uh cutter who
has a razor blade and in a
non-sterilized way and and they remove
the exterior parts of a woman's
genitalia. And then sometimes in more
extreme cases but not very rare cases
they sew the orifice up so the girl can
just urinate or mistrate and then later
when she gets married the same cutter
goes in and opens the orifice up so she
can have sex. This is not a rare thing
although it's against the law in most
countries. In Egypt for instance more
than 91% of all the females that live in
Egypt today have been sexually mutilated
in that way. In some countries, it's
more than 98% of the women are cut that
way before they reach maturity. This is
a horrible affliction on all women that
live in those countries. Another very
serious thing is honor killings where a
family with misinterpretation again of
the holy of scriptures, there's nothing
in the Quran that that mandates this,
will execute a girl in their family if
she is raped or if she marries a man
that her father does not approve or
sometimes even if she wears
inappropriate clothing and and this is
done by members of her own family. So
the family becomes murderous when the
girl brings so-called disgrace to the
family. An analysis was done in Egypt,
not so long ago, by the United Nations,
and it shows that 75% of these murders
of a girl are perpetrated by the father,
the uncle or the son, but of the
brother, but 25% of the murders are
conducted by women. Another problem that
we have in the world that relates to
women particularly is slavery or human
trafficking is called nowadays. There
were about 12 and a half million people
sold from Africa into slavery in the new
world back in the 19th century and the
18th century. There are 30 million
people now living in slavery. The United
States uh Department of State now has a
mandate from the Congress to to give a
report every year and and the State
Department reports that 800,000 people
are sold across international borders
every year into slavery. And that 80% of
those sold are women into sexual
slavery. In the United States right this
moment, 60,000 people are living in
human bondage or slavery. Atlanta,
Georgia, where the quarter center is
located and where where I teach at Emory
University, they have between 200 and
300 women people sold into slavery every
month. It's the number one place in the
in the nation because of that. Atlanta
has the busiest airport in the world and
they also have a lot of passengers that
come from from the southern hemisphere.
If a if a brothel owner wants to buy a
girl that has brown or black skin, they
can do it for $1,000.
A white skinned girl brings several
times more than that. And the average
brothel owner in Atlanta and and in the
United States now can earn about $35,000
per slave. The the sex trade in Atlanta,
Georgia exceeds the total drug trade in
Atlanta, Georgia. So this is another
very serious problem and and the basic
problem is prostitution because uh
there's not a there's not a wh house in
America that's not known by the local
officials, the the local policeman or
the chief of police or the mayor and so
forth. And this leads to one of the
worst problems and that is that women
are bought increasingly and put into
sexual slavery uh in all countries in
the world. Sweden has got a good
approach to it. About 15 or 20 years
ago, Sweden decided to change the law
and and women are no longer prosecuted
if they are in sexual slavery, but the
brothel owners and the pimps and the
male customers are prosecuted
and uh prostitution has gone down.
In the United States, we take just the
opposite position. For every male
arrested for illegal sex trade, 25 women
are arrested in the United States of
America.
Canada, Ireland,
I've already said Sweden, uh France and
other countries are moving now toward
this so-called Swedish model. That's
another thing that can be done.
We have two great institutions in this
country that all of us admire. our
military and our great university
system. In the military, they're now
analyzing how many sexual assaults take
place. The last report I got, there were
26,000 sexual assaults take that took
place in the military. 26,000 only. On
only 3,000, not more than much more than
1% are actually prosecuted. And the
reason is that the commanding officer of
any organization, a ship like my
submarine or a battalion in the army or
company in the Marines, the commanding
officer has a has the right under law to
decide whether to prosecute a rapist or
not. And of course, the last thing they
want is for anybody to know that under
their command, sexual assaults are
taking place. So they do not do it. That
that law needs to be changed.
about one out of four girls who enter
American universities will be sexually
assaulted before she graduates. And this
is now getting a lot of publicity,
partially because of my book, but other
things. And so 89 universities in
America are now condemned by the
Department of Education under Title N
because the officials of the
universities are not taking care of the
women to protect them from sexual
assault. The Department of Justice says
that more than half of the rapes on a
college campus take place by serial
rapist because outside the university
system they can if they rape somebody
they'll be prosecuted. But when they get
on a university campus they can rape
with impunity. They're not prosecuted.
Those are the kind of things that go on
in our in our society. Another thing
that's very serious about about the
abuse of of women and girls is a lack of
equal pay for for equal uh work as you
know. And
this is sometimes a bit disperate but
but for full-time employment
a woman in the United States now gets
23% less than a man. When I became
president the difference was 39%. So we
made some progress but partially because
I was president and so forth
but
but in the last 15 years there's been no
progress made. So it's been just about
23 or 24% difference for the last 15
years. These are the kind of things that
go on. If you take the the Fortune 500
companies,
23 of them have women CEOs out of 500.
And those CEOs, I need not tell you,
make less on an average than the other
CEOs.
Well, that's what goes on in our
country. Another thing that that's a
problem with the United States is that
we are the most warlike nation on earth.
We have been to war with about 25
different countries since the Second
World War. Sometimes we've had soldiers
on the ground fighting. The other times
we've been flying overhead, dropping
bombs on people. Other times, of course,
now we know we have drones that attack
people and so forth. We've been at war
with 25 different countries or more in
the last since the Second World War.
There was four years. I won't say which
ones when we didn't.
We didn't drop a bomb.
We didn't drop a bomb. We didn't launch
a missile. We didn't fire a bullet. But
anyway, those kind of things that result
to violence and the misinterpretation of
the holy scriptures are what causes are
the basic causes of abuse of women and
girls. There's one more basic cause that
I need not mention and that is that in
general men don't give a damn.
That's true. The average man that might
say I'm against the abuse of women and
girls quietly accepts the privilege
position that we occupy. And this is
very similar to what I knew when I was a
child when separate but equal had
existed racial racial discrimination
legally had existed for a hundred years
from 1865 at the end of the war between
the states of civil war all the way up
to 1900s 1960s when London Johnson got
it got the bills passed for equal
rights. But during that time, there were
many white people that didn't think that
racial discrimination was okay. But they
stayed quiet because they enjoy the
privileges of better jobs,
unique access to jury duty, better
schools, and everything else. And that's
the same thing that exists today because
the average man really doesn't care.
Even though they say I'm against
discrimination against girls and and and
and women, uh they enjoy a privileged
position. And it's very difficult to get
the majority of men who control the the
university system, the majority of men
that control the military system, the
majority of men that control the
governments of the world, and the
majority of men that controls the great
religions.
So what is the basic thing that we need
to do today?
I would say the best thing that we can
do today is for the women in the
powerful nations
like this one and where you come from
Europe and so forth who have influence
and who have freedom to speak and to act
need to take the responsibility on
yourselves
to be more forceful in demanding an end
to racial discrimination against girls
and and and and women all over the
world. The average woman in in uh Egypt
doesn't have much to say about her
daughters getting generally mutilated
and and so forth. I didn't go down to
detail about that. But I hope that out
of this conference that every woman here
will get your husbands to realize that
these abuses on the college campuses and
the military and so forth and in the
future job market need to protect your
daughters and your granddaughters. I
have uh 12 grandchildren, four children
and 10 great grandchildren. And I think
often about them and about the plight
that they will face in America, not only
if they lived in Egypt or some foreign
country in having equal rights. And I
hope that all of you will join me in
being a champion for women and girls
around the world and protect their human
rights. Thank you very much.
